The nation almost immediately fell into civil war that involved various factions fighting one another; these factions were often distinguished by clan loyalties. More than 500,000 residents fled during this time because of persecution, increased poverty and better economic opportunities in the West or in other former Soviet republics. Emomali Rahmon came to power in 1992, defeating former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in a November presidential election with 58% of the vote. The elections took place shortly after the end of the war, and Tajikistan was in a state of complete devastation. The estimated dead numbered over 100,000. Around 1.2 million people were refugees inside and outside of the country. In 1997, a ceasefire was reached between Rahmon and opposition parties under the guidance of Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary General, a result widely praised as a successful United Nations peace keeping initiative. The ceasefire guaranteed 30% of ministerial positions would go to the opposition. Elections were held in 1999, though they were criticized by opposition parties and foreign observers as unfair and Rahmon was re-elected with 98% of the vote. Elections in 2006 were again won by Rahmon (with 79% of the vote) and he began his third term in office. Several opposition parties boycotted the 2006 election and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) criticized it, although observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States claimed the elections were legal and transparent. Rahmon's administration came under further criticism from the OSCE in October 2010 for its censorship and repression of the media. The OSCE claimed that the Tajik Government censored Tajik and foreign websites and instituted tax inspections on independent printing houses that led to the cessation of printing activities for a number of independent newspapers.

Several explanations have been offered for Yale’s representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism that has existed at Yale since the 1960s, and the intellectual influence of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on many of the future candidates. Yale President Richard Levin attributes the run to Yale’s focus on creating "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional priority that began during the tenure of Yale Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and now president of Duke University, stated: "We do give very significant attention to orientation to the community in our admissions, and there is a very strong tradition of volunteerism at Yale." Yale historian Gaddis Smith notes "an ethos of organized activity" at Yale during the 20th century that led John Kerry to lead the Yale Political Union's Liberal Party, George Pataki the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman to manage the Yale Daily News. Camille Paglia points to a history of networking and elitism: "It has to do with a web of friendships and affiliations built up in school." CNN suggests that George W. Bush benefited from preferential admissions policies for the "son and grandson of alumni", and for a "member of a politically influential family." New York Times correspondent Elisabeth Bumiller and The Atlantic Monthly correspondent James Fallows credit the culture of community and cooperation that exists between students, faculty, and administration, which downplays self-interest and reinforces commitment to others.

The last major building work took place during the reign of King George V when, in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble in part Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. This new, refaced principal façade (of Portland stone) was designed to be the backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, a large memorial statue of Queen Victoria, placed outside the main gates. George V, who had succeeded Edward VII in 1910, had a more serious personality than his father; greater emphasis was now placed on official entertaining and royal duties than on lavish parties. He arranged a series of command performances featuring jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919) – the first jazz performance for a head of state, Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932), which earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival as one of the venues making the greatest contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom. George V's wife Queen Mary was a connoisseur of the arts, and took a keen interest in the Royal Collection of furniture and art, both restoring and adding to it. Queen Mary also had many new fixtures and fittings installed, such as the pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, dating from 1810, which the Queen had installed in the ground floor Bow Room, the huge low room at the centre of the garden façade. Queen Mary was also responsible for the decoration of the Blue Drawing Room. This room, 69 feet (21 metres) long, previously known as the South Drawing Room, has a ceiling designed specially by Nash, coffered with huge gilt console brackets.

The departures of Núñez and van Gaal were hardly noticed by the fans when compared to that of Luís Figo, then club vice-captain. Figo had become a cult hero, and was considered by Catalans to be one of their own. However, Barcelona fans were distraught by Figo's decision to join arch-rivals Real Madrid, and, during subsequent visits to the Camp Nou, Figo was given an extremely hostile reception. Upon his first return, a piglet's head and a full bottle of whiskey were thrown at him from the crowd. The next three years saw the club in decline, and managers came and went. van Gaal was replaced by Llorenç Serra Ferrer who, despite an extensive investment in players in the summer of 2000, presided over a mediocre league campaign and a humiliating first-round Champions League exit, and was eventually dismissed late in the season. Long-serving coach Carles Rexach was appointed as his replacement, initially on a temporary basis, and managed to at least steer the club to the last Champions League spot on the final day of the season. Despite better form in La Liga and a good run to the semi-finals of the Champions League, Rexach was never viewed as a long-term solution and that summer Louis van Gaal returned to the club for a second spell as manager. What followed, despite another decent Champions League performance, was one of the worst La Liga campaigns in the club's history, with the team as low as 15th in February 2003. This led to van Gaal's resignation and replacement for the rest of the campaign by Radomir Antić, though a sixth-place finish was the best that he could manage. At the end of the season, Antić's short-term contract was not renewed, and club president Joan Gaspart resigned, his position having been made completely untenable by such a disastrous season on top

In 1954, a pivotal moment unfolded in the linguistic landscape of the Balkans when prominent Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists, and literary critics, with the support of Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska, signed the Novi Sad Agreement. The agreement's foremost assertion was that the Serbs, Croats, and Montenegrins shared a single language, manifesting in two equally valid variants that evolved around the cultural hubs of Zagreb (western) and Belgrade (eastern). It championed the equal status of both Cyrillic and Latin scripts, alongside the Ekavian and Ijekavian pronunciations. Furthermore, it designated "Serbo-Croatian" as the official language name, while allowing the traditional names, Serbian and Croatian, to persist in informal contexts. In a collaborative spirit, Matica hrvatska and Matica srpska embarked on crafting a unified dictionary, while a committee of Serbian and Croatian linguists undertook the task of preparing a pravopis, a comprehensive orthography guide. By the 1960s, these efforts bore fruit, resulting in simultaneous publications in Ijekavian Latin in Zagreb and Ekavian Cyrillic in Novi Sad. 

However, Croatian linguists voiced concerns, characterizing the agreement as a move towards unitarianism. Yet, the evidence supporting this claim was inconsistent. For instance, Croatian linguist Stjepan Babić criticized the consistent use of the Latin alphabet in television broadcasts from Belgrade, a practice born from practicality and prestige rather than inequality. Babić also objected to the Novi Sad Dictionary (1967) presenting Croatian and Serbian variant words side by side, which could equally be seen as a testament to the diligent acknowledgment of both linguistic traditions, rather than a unifying imposition. Some Croatian linguists paradoxically criticized as unitaristic those sections of the Dictionary crafted by their own colleagues, and overlooked the fact that the material for the Pravopisni rječnik stemmed from the Croatian Philological Society.

Despite these nuanced realities, Croatian intellectuals responded with the Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Literary Language in 1967, marking a stand for linguistic

The Bush administration soon shifted its focus to Iraq, arguing that the urgency of removing Saddam Hussein from power had intensified. Their rationale included claims that Saddam's regime was attempting to acquire nuclear materials and had not adequately accounted for its known stockpiles of biological and chemical weapons, suspected to still be in its possession. These actions, according to the administration, violated U.N. sanctions. Despite fervent assertions of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction (WMD) from the outset, key international players such as China, France, Germany, and Russia remained skeptical and blocked a UN Security Council resolution endorsing the use of force. In November 2002, Iraq allowed UN weapons inspectors to resume their work, aiming to verify the WMD allegations. However, before their assessments were completed, the Bush administration chose to initiate military action without UN approval, instructing inspectors to withdraw. On March 20, 2003, the United States led an invasion with a "coalition of the willing," which included significant contributions from the United Kingdom and smaller contingents from Australia and Poland. Within three weeks, the Iraqi government and its military crumbled, yet the anticipated WMDs were nowhere to be found. Although some remnants of past materials and weapons labs were reported, no decisive evidence emerged. Nonetheless, on May 1, President George W. Bush made a dramatic appearance on the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln, declaring the end of "major combat operations" in Iraq. His approval rating peaked at 66% that month, according to a CNN–USA Today–Gallup poll. However, this support was ephemeral. While the initial military success was applauded, the prolonged efforts to reconstruct and "democratize" Iraq gradually lost favor as violence persisted, casualties mounted, and stability remained elusive. Furthermore, as investigations failed to uncover the predicted WMD stockpiles, the initial justification for the war became a point of contention and debate.

An adolescent's environment significantly influences their identity development. Although many studies focus on white, middle-class children, research indicates that a more privileged upbringing is often associated with more successful identity development. The process of forming an adolescent's identity is a critical phase in their life. Recent findings suggest that the transition to adulthood now spans a longer period compared to the mid-20th century, making the phase of youth, which encompasses late adolescence and early adulthood, a more prominent stage in the life course. Consequently, various factors have gained importance during this developmental period. Numerous elements contribute to the evolving social identity of adolescents, including commitment, coping mechanisms, and social media, all of which are influenced by the environment in which they grow up. Adolescents from more privileged backgrounds typically have access to greater opportunities and more favorable circumstances. In contrast, those from inner-city or high-crime areas may encounter environments detrimental to their development. Adolescence is a particularly sensitive time in the developmental process, and exposure to negative influences can significantly impact future decision-making. While children from suburban communities may not face adverse environments, they are often more engaged in activities that support identity formation and contribute to more successful identity development.

In the realm of team sports, the National Football League's preseason stands as a paragon of meticulous organization. Each year, every NFL team engages in precisely four preseason exhibition contests—two gracing the home turf and two unfolding on foreign soil. A notable exception emerges as two teams annually participate in a fifth spectacle, the revered Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These exhibitions, predominantly clustered in August, serve a vital purpose: they furnish coaches with the opportunity to sculpt their rosters, whittling down from an offseason bounty of 90 hopefuls to the lean, formidable cadre of 53 that will face the regular season. 

Although the scheduling of these preseason encounters lacks the ironclad regimentation of their regular-season counterparts, a tapestry of restrictions and time-honored traditions weaves a narrow path for the selection of adversaries. Moreover, the calendar imposes constraints on the days and hours these matches may unfold. Unlike their baseball and hockey brethren, NFL teams are forbidden from indulging in split-squad games, a practice where a team, destined to engage in dual matches on the same day, divides its forces into two squads.

In an effort to expand its global footprint, the NFL has staged these exhibition games on far-flung fields spanning Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, and Mexico. The ambitious notion of a game on Chinese soil was entertained, yet ultimately thwarted by financial and logistical hurdles. The league has also discreetly barred contests against non-league opponents; the last interleague skirmish took place in 1972, and the final bout against a non-NFL team—the College All-Stars—occurred in 1976.

Despite their role in shaping the season's warriors, these exhibition games are often met with disdain from fans, who balk at the prospect of paying regular-season prices for what they perceive as mere warm-ups included in their season-ticket bundles. This discontent has sparked a litany of legal battles, as disgruntled fans and their cohorts have sought redress through the courts, albeit to no avail. In the electrifying world of professional wrestling, not every infraction under the glaring arena lights leads to the echoing clank of a disqualification bell. Often, the referee, wielding authority with the finesse of a seasoned ringmaster, exercises discretion like an artist with a palette of judgment, deciding which breaches merit immediate consequence. Typically, the infractions that draw the referee's swift and decisive hand include the unmistakable thud of a low blow, the illicit gleam of a hidden weapon, the chaotic intrusion of an outsider, or the brazen audacity of striking the referee himself.

In the world of WWE, the sanctity of the referee's gaze is paramount—only violations caught by their eyes can bring a match to a screeching halt. The recorded tapes may capture the drama, but they rarely sway the ironclad verdict rendered by the referee's whistle. Yet, in the unpredictable theater of wrestling, the notorious "Dusty finish" sometimes sweeps in like a dramatic twist of fate, named after the legendary Dusty Rhodes, overturning what seemed final with a flourish.

Intrigue heightens as referees, those vigilant sentinels of the squared circle, occasionally find themselves sprawled on the canvas, victims of a "ref bump." As the referee lies "unconscious," the ropes transform into tightropes of chaos, where wrestlers seize the opportunity to bend rules until order is restored. In this momentary lapse of lawful oversight, mischief runs rampant, fueling the crowd's fervor.

In the heart of the 15th century, a majestic dome was gracefully added, while the naves stretched ambitiously behind the choir, seamlessly marrying the structure to the tower and crafting a grand main entrance. The ambitious Archbishop Luis Alfonso de los Cameros embarked on constructing the main chapel in 1674, adorning its walls with sumptuous marbles and gleaming bronzes that captured the opulent Baroque essence of the era. At the dawn of the 18th century, the German artisan Conrad Rudolphus meticulously sculpted the façade of the main entrance, adding a layer of grandeur. The cathedral boasts two additional doors leading into the transept: the Door of the Apostles, a pure embodiment of pointed Gothic elegance from the 14th century, and the Paláu door. However, the extensions at the cathedral's rear subtly diminished its towering splendor. The 18th-century renovations rounded the once-soaring pointed arches, cloaked the Gothic columns in stately Corinthian pillars, and infused the walls with new zest. The dome, though lacking a lantern, is illuminated by two generous side windows. Flanking either side are four chapels, augmented by those nestled at the end, and those that open into the choir, transept, and sanctuary, each whispering tales of artistry. The cathedral houses a trove of paintings by distinguished artists, though the silver reredos once gracing the altar was transformed into coin during the tumult of the 1808 war. The San Francesco chapel proudly displays two masterpieces by Francisco Goya. Tucked behind the Chapel of the Blessed Sacrament is a quaint Renaissance chapel, a creation of Pope Calixtus III. The initial reviews of the show presented a varied range of opinions. Ken Tucker of Entertainment Weekly remarked that "As TV, American Idol is crazily entertaining; as music, it's dust-mote inconsequential." Conversely, some observers noted that "the most striking aspect of the series was the genuine talent it revealed." The program was also characterized as a "sadistic musical bake-off" and "a romp in humiliation." Furthermore, the show faced criticism for various aspects, particularly its noticeable product placement. Critics harshly criticized the perceived blatant commercial motives, with Karla Peterson of The San Diego Union-Tribune describing American Idol as "a conniving multimedia monster" that has "absorbed the sin of our debauched culture and spit them out in a lump of reconstituted evil." The decision to have the season one winner perform the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial on the first anniversary of the September 11 attacks in 2002 was also poorly received by many. Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post sarcastically commented that "The terrorists have won" and criticized the show's commercialism and voting process, noting that the decision of who "gets to turn this important site into just another cog in the 'Great American Idol Marketing Mandala' is in the hands of the millions of girls who have made American Idol a hit, along with a handful of phone-redialer enthusiasts who have been recording up to 10,000 calls each week for their preferred contestant (but who, according to Fox, are in absolutely no way skewing the outcome)."

Back in the 1980s, the media was absolutely buzzing with stories about the royal family, and let's just say not all of them were straight out of a history book. Kelvin MacKenzie, who was the editor of The Sun, famously told his team, “Just give me a juicy story on the Royals for the Monday headlines. Truth? Well, that’s optional, as long as there’s no big fallout afterward.” Donald Trelford of The Observer chimed in on September 21, 1986, pointing out how royal coverage had morphed into a soap opera, with truth and fiction tangled up in a messy knot. He noted how some papers didn’t bother checking facts or even cared whether their stories were true. 

Around that time, The Sunday Times, on July 20, 1986, reported that the Queen was concerned about Margaret Thatcher’s policies, which seemed to be driving a wedge through society, causing unemployment, riots, and striking miners. They also claimed she was uneasy with Thatcher’s stance against imposing sanctions on apartheid South Africa. These whispers were said to have originated from folks like royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, though Shea insisted his words were twisted and blown up by speculation. Meanwhile, it was rumored that Thatcher joked about the Queen leaning toward the Social Democratic Party, which was quite contrary to Thatcher’s own politics. Thatcher’s biographer, John Campbell, called this a case of journalistic mischief-making.

Despite the rumored friction, Thatcher eventually expressed deep admiration for the Queen. In turn, the Queen honored Thatcher with the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter after John Major succeeded her as Prime Minister. And according to former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, the Queen played a quiet but significant role in the push to end apartheid.

From here, you can access the regal Throne Room and the vibrant Green Drawing Room, an impressive anteroom leading to the throne itself, starting from the Guard Room atop the Grand Staircase. In the Guard Room, you'll find statues of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, cast in marble and adorned in Roman costume, set against a backdrop of rich tapestries.

To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control over Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally spearheaded military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia. Through these efforts, he successfully expelled Galdan's invading forces, allowing these regions to be incorporated into the empire. Galdan met his end during the Dzungar–Qing War. In 1683, Qing forces accepted the surrender of Taiwan from Zheng Keshuang, the grandson of Koxinga, who had previously seized Taiwan from Dutch colonists to use as a base against the Qing. Zheng Keshuang was granted the title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and was integrated into the Han Chinese Plain Red Banner of the Eight Banners upon his relocation to Beijing. Several Ming princes had accompanied Koxinga to Taiwan in 1661-1662, including the Prince of Ningjing, Zhu Shugui, and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), son of Zhu Yihai, where they resided in the Kingdom of Tungning. In 1683, the Qing relocated the 17 surviving Ming princes on Taiwan back to mainland China, where they lived in exile, their executions spared. The capture of Taiwan liberated Kangxi's forces for a series of skirmishes over Albazin, the eastern outpost of the Tsardom of Russia. Former soldiers of Zheng, such as the rattan shield troops, were inducted into the Eight Banners and utilized by the Qing in conflicts against Russian Cossacks at Albazin. The 1689 Treaty of Nerchinsk, China's first formal treaty with a European power, ensured a peaceful border for nearly two centuries. Following Galdan's death, his Tibetan Buddhist followers attempted to influence the selection of the next Dalai Lama. In response, Kangxi sent two armies to Lhasa, Tibet's capital, to install a Dalai Lama sympathetic to the Qing.

Starting in the 1970s, Stuart Hall, along with his dynamic team of thinkers like Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and Angela McRobbie, sparked an international intellectual movement that truly transformed the landscape of cultural studies. As this exciting field took shape, it began to weave together an array of disciplines—political economy, communication, sociology, literary and media theory, film studies, cultural anthropology, philosophy, museum studies, and art history. All these threads come together to explore cultural phenomena and texts.

Researchers in this field are often intrigued by how specific phenomena connect to ideology, nationality, ethnicity, social class, and gender. Cultural studies delve into the rich tapestry of everyday life, examining how people engage in ordinary activities—like watching TV or dining out—and the meanings they attach to these experiences. It’s about understanding those cultural practices and meanings that exist beyond logical reasoning. For instance, tuning into a show to catch up on a historical event isn’t necessarily culture unless we consider the cultural choice of the medium itself. However, schoolchildren gathering around the TV after school to hang out with friends definitely fits the bill—there’s no rational reason for it, yet it’s an essential cultural experience.

As capitalism continues to spread across the globe—a phenomenon we call globalization—cultural studies have turned an analytical eye towards the ways local and global communities resist Western dominance. In this context, globalization often means the westernization of other cultures, sometimes eroding their cultural uniqueness in repressive and exploitative ways. Yet, not all hearts beat in time with these changes. Among the bustling streets, murmurs of dissent rose into public demonstrations, a chorus of resistance against the reforms. By 2010, ambitious plans unfurled, envisioning half of the Libyan economy privatized within a decade. Despite the absence of political liberalization, Gaddafi's reign remained unyielding, even as March 2010 saw the government bestow more powers upon municipal councils, a step towards decentralization.

Rising through this complex symphony of reform were the reformist technocrats, with Gaddafi's son, Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, emerging as a prominent soloist. A critic of Libya's human rights record, Saif led a movement to draft a new constitution, though its notes never found harmony in adoption. Mammalian hair, or pelage, exhibits a wide range of color variations, not only between different populations but also among individuals within the same population, and even within a single organism. Light and dark color variations are prevalent across various mammalian taxa. While age can be a factor in determining these color differences, other influences are often at play. Selective pressures, such as interactions with other populations and environmental conditions, frequently drive changes in mammalian coloration. These pressures often favor specific colors that enhance an organism’s chances of survival. Camouflage is widely considered a significant selective force in the evolution of mammalian coloration, although sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes also play crucial roles.

Camouflage primarily aids in concealing organisms from predators or prey, making it the predominant mechanism for color variation. Additionally, coat color serves various communication purposes within species, such as warning conspecifics about predators, signaling health for reproduction, facilitating mother-offspring communication, and deterring predators. Research indicates that differences in coat color between females and males can reveal nutritional status and hormone levels, which are critical in mate selection. Furthermore, coat color can reflect physiological adaptations, like temperature regulation in extreme climates, whether tropical or arctic.

Despite significant observations on color variation, much remains unknown about the genetic underpinnings linking coat color to specific genes. The genetic loci associated with pigmentation impact the phenotype by either altering the spatial distribution of hair pigmentation or changing the density and distribution of hairs. Quantitative trait mapping is employed to better comprehend the loci responsible for pigmentation variation. However, even with the identification of these genetic sites, much remains to be discovered about gene expression mechanisms and their influence on coat color.

During the mid-18th century, amidst the intellectual currents of the French Enlightenment, the term "humanism" began to take on a more ideological significance. In 1765, an anonymous writer in a French Enlightenment publication articulated the concept of a "general love of humanity," describing it as a virtue previously unacknowledged, and suggesting the term "humanism" to encapsulate this beautiful and necessary ideal. As the 18th century waned and the 19th century dawned, a wave of grassroots philanthropic and benevolent societies emerged, committed to human betterment and the dissemination of knowledge—some secular, others rooted in Christian values.

In the aftermath of the French Revolution, the proposition that human virtue could arise solely from human reason, independent of religious institutions, faced fierce opposition. Critics, including influential figures like Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre, argued fervently against this Enlightenment notion, particularly as espoused by thinkers like Rousseau, viewing it as a dangerous elevation of humanity to a divine status. Consequently, "humanism" began to carry a negative connotation. The Oxford English Dictionary notes the term's use in 1812 by an English clergyman to describe those, like Unitarians and Deists, who believed in the "mere humanity" of Christ, distinguishing them from orthodox views regarding His divine nature.

In this polarized climate, where established religious bodies often resisted political and social reforms such as extending voting rights and implementing universal education, liberal reformers and radicals found in Humanism an appealing philosophy—a secular "religion of humanity." The anarchist Proudhon, renowned for proclaiming "property is theft," characterized humanism as a "cult, deification of humanity." Meanwhile, Ernest Renan, in his work "L’avenir de la science: pensées de 1848" ("The Future of Knowledge: Thoughts on 1848"), expressed his profound belief that pure humanism would become the future's religion, venerating all aspects of human life and elevating them to moral significance.

In the ever-evolving landscape of politics, the dynamics of coalition governments have taken center stage, particularly in multi-party systems where no single party can wield power on its own. The Republic of Ireland, since the 1980s, has exemplified this trend, with coalition governments becoming the norm. Similarly, in Germany, both nationally and at the state level, as well as in many local constituencies, coalition-building is a staple of political strategy. Iceland also stands as a testament to this approach, never having seen a government not led by a coalition since its formation, typically involving the Independence Party alongside the Social Democratic Alliance.

In the Republic of Ireland, since 1989, no party has governed independently. Coalition governments, primarily led by Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael, have become the standard. This collaborative form of governance can facilitate political change more readily than systems dominated by one or two parties. In such systems, deep-seated disagreements on policy or principles can stymie progress, a situation currently observable in the United States where Democrats and Republicans remain at an impasse. However, coalition governments face their own challenges, sometimes struggling for years to enact policy changes, as evidenced by the post-World War II experiences of France and Italy.

Conversely, in a two-party system where one party gains control of all elective branches, sweeping policy changes can occur with remarkable speed and impact. This was the case during the administrations of Democrats like Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson, as well as Republicans such as Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. Even Barack Obama experienced a brief period of such advantage between 2009 and 2011.

Nestled within the heart of a tranquil countryside, a serene scene unfolds, capturing the essence of nature's gentle embrace. Lush green meadows stretch endlessly, their vibrant hues singing in harmony with the earth. The gentle babbling brook winds its way through the landscape, its crystal-clear waters dancing over smooth stones, creating a soothing melody that lulls the senses into a peaceful reverie. Dotted throughout the meadows, a tapestry of colorful wildflowers sways gracefully in the soft breeze, their petals a vivid display of nature's palette, ranging from brilliant blues and radiant reds to sunlit yellows and delicate purples. Each flower moves in unison with the wind, creating a rhythmic dance that mirrors the whispers of the breeze. This tranquil setting evokes a deep sense of calm and connection, much like the intricate web of emotions that motivate social interactions and relationships. Emotions, intrinsically tied to our physiology and stress systems, play a pivotal role in bonding, akin to the oxytocin-attachment system. They shape our social connectedness and fitness within complex social systems, a trait we share with other species, intricately woven into our DNA. Just as the meadows and brook have thrived through time, zygotes inherit the genetic legacy of their ancestors, ensuring survival and adaptation. In the tapestry of life, minor genetic variations can give rise to significant behavioral differences, as seen in the nuanced social structures of voles or the eloquence bestowed upon humans by the FOXP2 gene. This genetic symphony underscores the foundations of emotions, speech, and social organization, mirroring the harmonious beauty of the countryside scene before us.

The current landscape of research increasingly employs the concept of identity to explore various phenomena, albeit with some ambiguity regarding the precise timeline of this trend. A notable area where identity plays a crucial role is within occupational settings, particularly in jobs perceived as stigmatized or "dirty work" (Hughes, 1951). Tracy and Trethewey (2005) argue that individuals gravitate towards or shy away from certain occupations based, in part, on how well these roles align with their "preferred organizational self" (p. 169). Jobs are often attached with various stigmas or accolades, affecting how individuals perceive and justify their occupational choices. Tracy's analysis highlights correctional officers, who strive to overcome the stigma of being deemed "glorified maids" (Tracy & Trethewey, 2005). The process of establishing justifications and values for occupational choices can significantly impact workplace satisfaction and overall quality of life (Tracy & Scott, 2006, p. 33). Those engaged in stigmatized jobs are compelled to construct a personal identity that is congruent with their self-perception. Crafting a positive sense of self becomes particularly daunting when one's work is considered "dirty" by societal standards (Tracy & Scott, 2006, p. 7). Employees in such positions must deftly manage the taint associated with their work, often transforming it into a badge of honor to maintain a positive identity. However, when confronted with discourses questioning the legitimacy of their work, employees might resort to blaming clients as a strategy to affirm their identity (Tracy & Scott, 2006, p. 33).

In their 2003 paper, "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races," Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles provide a comprehensive critique of the application of FST to human populations. They challenge the commonly cited figure of 85%, which suggests that each human population contains, on average, 85% of all genetic diversity. Long and Kittles argue that this figure is misleading because it inaccurately implies that human groups are independent and equally diverse. Instead, they propose a more nuanced understanding of human population history, emphasizing that some groups serve as ancestral or "parental" populations for others, creating what are known as paraphyletic groups. 

For instance, based on the recent African origin theory, the populations in Africa are considered paraphyletic to all other human groups, indicating that they are the ancestral source of all non-African populations. Importantly, non-African populations stem from a small, non-representative sample of the African genetic pool. This results in non-African groups being more closely related to each other and to certain African groups, such as East Africans, than to other African populations. Moreover, the migration out of Africa is characterized by a genetic bottleneck, where much of the original diversity was not carried by those who left the continent.

This perspective reshapes our understanding of human population movements, illustrating not an independence among populations, but rather a pattern of genetic dilution the further a population is from Africa. Each migratory event signifies a founder effect, where only a subset of the parental population's genetic diversity is passed on. Long and Kittles conclude that, contrary to the 85% figure, nearly all human genetic diversity can be found within a single African population, while a population from a place like New Guinea might only reflect about 70% of this diversity. Despite this, they assert that the global human population remains genetically homogeneous, especially when compared to other mammalian species.

The saga of translating Darwin's groundbreaking work was a journey fraught with challenges and unforeseen twists, as if each translation bore its own soul and spirit, echoing the complex dance between science and society. During Darwin's lifetime, his revolutionary ideas traversed linguistic borders, seeking to find kindred spirits who could faithfully convey the nuances of his theories. Yet, the path was not smooth; it was marred by the shadows of misinterpretation and the personal biases of those who wielded the pen.

In France and Germany, Darwin extended the olive branch of scholarly collaboration, distributing presentation copies with the hope that worthy translators would emerge from the intellectual woodwork. He found an ally in Heinrich Georg Bronn, a venerable naturalist and geologist whose reputation preceded him. However, the German translation that saw the light in 1860 was not without its thorns. Bronn, perhaps overwhelmed by the gravity of his task, infused the work with his own philosophical leanings, adding contentious themes that Darwin had intentionally eschewed. The phrase "favoured races" morphed into "perfected races," a change laden with implications, while Bronn's essays ventured into the murky waters of life's origins and religious discourse, reflecting his devotion to Naturphilosophie.

Despite Bronn's sudden departure in 1862, Darwin's spirit remained undeterred, finding solace in the meticulous work of Julius Victor Carus, who released an enhanced German translation in 1867. Meanwhile, across the Channel, Darwin's aspirations in France were met with frustration. Clémence Royer's 1862 translation, though ambitious, was punctuated with her introduction extolling Darwin as a rival to divine revelation, and notes that leaned towards a nascent social Darwinism and eugenics. Though Darwin endeavored to purify future editions, the shadow of Royer's interpretations loomed large until Edmond Barbier's translation in 1876 finally assuaged his concerns.

Hegel's philosophical project seeks to retain the core truths of German idealism, particularly Kant's proposition that ethical reason transcends mere finite inclinations. For Hegel, a synthesis of thought and being is fundamental for a "subject" (any human observer) to apprehend any "object" (any external entity, potentially including other humans). This is encapsulated in Hegel's notion of "subject-object identity," wherein both subject and object share Spirit (Hegel’s reinterpretation of a non-supernatural "God") as their core conceptual reality—rendering them identical in essence. However, until Spirit achieves "self-realization" and ascends to the status of Absolute Spirit, the subject (a human mind) erroneously perceives every "object" as an "alien," or something distinct and separate from itself. Hegel articulates this misunderstanding: "The object is revealed to it [to the 'subject'] as something alien, and it does not recognize itself." Self-realization emerges when Hegel—understood as an embodiment of Spirit's non-supernatural Mind, which is collectively the mind of all humanity—recognizes that every "object" is intrinsically part of himself, as both subject and object are manifestations of Spirit. Upon this realization, when Spirit evolves into Absolute Spirit, the finite (human) transforms into the infinite (divine), supplanting the erstwhile supernatural God of theism with a new paradigm: man becomes God. As Tucker aptly summarizes, "Hegelianism... is a religion of self-worship whose fundamental theme is given in Hegel's image of the man who aspires to be God himself, who demands 'something more, namely infinity.'" Hegel thus presents a vision of "a self-glorifying humanity striving compulsively, and ultimately successfully, to rise to divinity."

In the annals of ancient history, the Israelites twice reveled in the sweet air of political independence. Their first taste came during the era of the Biblical judges, followed by the illustrious reign of the United Monarchy. Yet, with the fall of this unity, the once seamless land was cleaved into the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. From the latter, the term "Jew" unfurled, a linguistic evolution from the Roman "Judean," designating those who hailed from the southern realm of Judah. This transformation of identity, while absent in the Torah, finds its voice in the Book of Esther, penned in the 4th century BCE, nestled within the revered Ketuvim of the Jewish Tanakh.

In the year 587 BCE, the ominous shadow of Nebuchadnezzar II, sovereign of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, darkened Jerusalem. His forces besieged the sacred city, razing the First Temple to the ground and leading away Judah's eminent souls into exile. By 586 BCE, the kingdom of Judah had crumbled, leaving its people adrift and bereft of sovereignty. But the wheel of fortune turned once more in 539 BCE, as the Achaemenid Empire vanquished Babylon. Cyrus the Great, with a magnanimous decree, beckoned the exiled Jews to return to their ancestral home of Yehud and restore their cherished Temple. By 515 BCE, the Second Temple stood proudly, a testament to resilience, within a Yehud that slumbered peacefully under Achaemenid rule until Alexander the Great's conquests circa 333 BCE.

In 1919, following the Treaty of Versailles, Strasbourg was returned to France as dictated by U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's "Fourteen Points," bypassing a local referendum. The city's reassignment was symbolically backdated to Armistice Day. A referendum might not have favored France, given that political factions advocating for Alsatian autonomy or alignment with France had garnered only a minority of votes in both the Reichstag and local elections. Notably, Alsatian autonomists with pro-French leanings had secured considerable support in rural areas and other towns since the German annexation in 1871. This movement took root with the initial Reichstag election, where those elected, known as "les députés protestataires," were the sole representatives advocating for the return of Alsace to France until Bismarck's fall in 1890. In the latest Reichstag election before the city’s transfer, Social Democrats emerged victorious in Strasbourg and its surroundings. As the administrative hub of the region, Strasbourg housed many Germans appointed by Berlin, and its robust economy attracted numerous German residents. This demographic and political landscape contributed to the disparity between rural and urban voting patterns. Following the war, a significant exodus of Germans ensued, with many leaving Strasbourg under pressure from denunciations or expulsions by the newly established authorities. The Saverne Affair remained a potent reminder of past tensions among the Alsatians.

Ladies and gentlemen, today I would like to highlight the vibrant and dynamic economic landscape of Zhejiang. Renowned for its diverse manufacturing sectors—ranging from electromechanical and textiles to chemicals, food, and construction materials—Zhejiang has charted a unique course with what is known as the "Zhejiang model." This model emphasizes fostering entrepreneurship, supporting agile small businesses, investing heavily in infrastructure, and producing affordable goods for both domestic and international markets. Such strategies have propelled Zhejiang to become one of China's wealthiest provinces, with the "Zhejiang spirit" becoming legendary across the nation.

However, it is crucial to address some growing concerns among economists about the sustainability of this model. They argue it may be inefficient and heavily reliant on raw materials and public utilities. Additionally, the focus on numerous small businesses producing low-cost goods may limit the province’s ability to transition into more sophisticated, technologically advanced industries. 

Geographically, the economic epicenter of Zhejiang has shifted from the north, around Hangzhou, to the southeast, encompassing areas like Wenzhou and Taizhou. In 2009, urban residents enjoyed a per capita disposable income of 24,611 yuan (approximately US$3,603), reflecting an impressive real growth of 8.3% annually, while rural residents saw a per capita income of 10,007 yuan (around US$1,465), a growth of 8.1% year-on-year. By 2011, Zhejiang's nominal GDP had soared to 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion), with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). The province's primary, secondary, and tertiary industries reported values of 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion) respectively.

In those whimsical yet tumultuous early days of home entertainment, the venerable MCA embarked on a journey that would see it crafting discs for cinematic giants like Paramount, Disney, and Warner Bros. These iconic studios, eager to leave their indelible mark on the medium, occasionally graced the disc jackets with their own illustrious names, a proud declaration of ownership amidst the burgeoning videodisc revolution. However, the vibrant symphony of DiscoVision Associates came to an abrupt halt in early 1982, leaving MCA's videodisc wing to rise from the ashes. Reborn as MCA Videodisc, it nostalgically resurrected many beloved DiscoVision titles, albeit with a bittersweet twist. Classics like Battlestar Galactica and Jaws were reissued in time-compressed versions, echoing faintly of their original splendor.

The reimagined CLV edition of Jaws, stripped of its haunting original soundtrack, was a muted echo of its former self, the vibrant notes stifled by licensing constraints. It wasn't until the THX LaserDisc box set graced the world in 1995 that the full auditory experience was restored, a long-awaited reunion with the film's soul. Meanwhile, the poignant saga of The Electric Horseman unfolded—a Universal/Columbia gem, preserved by MCA DiscoVision in both CAV and CLV forms. Yet, even today, its original musical score remains an elusive treasure, with every subsequent DVD release marred by music substitutions, Willie Nelson's soulful tunes lost in the shuffle.

In Southeast Europe, agrarian societies emerged as early as the 7th millennium BC, as evidenced by one of Europe's earliest farming sites, discovered in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania, dating back to 6500 BC. Anthropomorphic figurines have been unearthed in the Balkans from 6000 BC and in Central Europe by approximately 5800 BC, notably at La Hoguette. Among the initial cultural complexes in this region is the Sesklo culture in Thessaly, which later expanded into the Balkans, giving rise to the Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča cultures. These Neolithic traditions proliferated through cultural diffusion and migration, reaching northwestern Europe by around 4500 BC. The Vinča culture may have developed one of the earliest systems of writing, known as the Vinča signs, though archaeologist Shan Winn suggests they likely represented pictograms and ideograms rather than a fully developed writing system. The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture constructed vast settlements in Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine from 5300 to 2300 BC. The megalithic temple complexes of Ġgantija on the Mediterranean island of Gozo and Mnajdra in Malta are remarkable for their colossal Neolithic structures, with the oldest dating back to approximately 3600 BC. The Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni in Paola, Malta, is a subterranean structure excavated around 2500 BC; initially a sanctuary, it later became a necropolis, distinguished as the only prehistoric underground temple globally, showcasing unique artistry in stone sculpture specific to the Maltese islands. Following 2500 BC, the Maltese Islands experienced a temporary depopulation, which lasted several decades until the arrival of a new influx of Bronze Age settlers, characterized by a culture that practiced cremation and introduced smaller megalithic structures known as dolmens. These structures often feature small chambers with large cover slabs supported by upright stones and are believed to have been constructed by a population distinct from the builders of the earlier megalithic temples. It is presumed that this population arrived from Sicily, given the resemblance of Maltese dolmens to similar small constructions found on the Mediterranean's largest island.

In his conceptualization of knowledge, Karl Popper posits that it possesses an objective nature—not only in terms of its truth value but also regarding its ontological status as an entity independent of the knowing subject. In his work "Objective Knowledge: An Evolutionary Approach" (1972), Popper delineates three distinct "worlds" to articulate his theory: World One, which encompasses the tangible, physical realm; World Two, representing the realm of mental states, ideas, and perceptions; and World Three, which consists of the cumulative body of human knowledge manifest in various forms—such as books, artworks, and symphonies. Popper argues that World Three, much like an animal path is shaped by individual animals, is constructed by individual human efforts and yet evolves independently from any single knowing individual. He asserts that the influence of World Three on individual cognition (World Two) is at least as significant as the impact of the physical world (World One). Thus, an individual's understanding is as much shaped by the extensive repository of human knowledge as by direct experiential encounters. Consequently, the evolution of human knowledge can be viewed as intrinsically linked to the autonomous development of World Three. Despite the compelling nature of Popper's argument, many contemporary philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, remain skeptical of his Three Worlds theory, primarily due to its perceived parallelism with mind-body dualism.

The strict separation of powers was not a feature of the United Kingdom's political system, which often served as a model for the U.S. Constitution. The UK’s Westminster system, characterized by parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government, positioned Parliament—comprising the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons—as the supreme legislative authority. The executive functioned in the name of the King ("His Majesty's Government"), overlapping with the judiciary. Notably, the King's Ministers were typically members of one of the two Houses of Parliament, necessitating the Government to maintain majority support in the House of Commons. A striking example of this overlap is the position of the Lord Chancellor, who simultaneously acted as the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and as the presiding officer in the House of Lords. This illustrates that the British government frequently breached the strict principle of separation of powers, despite instances of inter-branch disagreement. Similarly, in the 18th-century United States, some states did not strictly adhere to this principle. In New Jersey, for example, the Governor served as both a member of the state's highest court and as the presiding officer of one house of the Legislature. The President of Delaware was part of the Court of Appeals, while the presiding officers of its legislature also held executive roles as Vice Presidents. In Delaware and Pennsylvania, members of the executive council concurrently served as judges. However, many southern states explicitly mandated a separation of powers. States like Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and Georgia insisted on keeping their governmental branches "separate and distinct."

Ottoman madrasas, despite offering diverse branches of study such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, primarily functioned as Islamic centers for spiritual learning. The ultimate aim of all knowledge, particularly spiritual sciences, was to attain a deeper understanding of God. Religion significantly influenced the perceived importance of each science. As İnalcık notes, "Those which aid religion are good, and sciences like astrology are bad." Although subjects like mathematics and logic were included in the madrasa curriculum, they were intrinsically linked to religious teachings. Even mathematics was taught with a religious impetus, as the Ottoman ulema believed that disciplines like logic and mathematics fostered correct thinking, thereby unveiling divine truths—emphasizing the "divine" aspect. Philosophy, too, was permitted only to the extent that it supported Islamic doctrines. Therefore, madrasas essentially served as religious centers for Islamic education in the Ottoman Empire. While scholars like Goffman argue that the Ottomans practiced tolerance and lived in a pluralistic society, it appears that these centers of learning were predominantly religious, focusing primarily on Islam. Similarly, in Europe, Jewish children learned Hebrew and basic prayers at home before attending synagogue-organized schools to study the Torah. Wiesner-Hanks notes that Protestants also sought to instill "proper religious values." This indicates that during the early modern period, both Ottomans and Europeans shared similar educational philosophies regarding the management and focus of schools. Thus, Ottoman madrasas were akin to contemporary educational institutions in offering a broad spectrum of studies; however, these studies ultimately aimed to reinforce and consolidate Islamic practices and theories.

The central and northern regions of Thuringia are characterized by the expansive Thuringian Basin, which spans 3,000 square kilometers. This very fertile and flat area, centered around the Unstrut River, is encircled by a series of hill chains, which include the Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge, and Hainich, in a clockwise direction from the northwest. Within the Basin, smaller hill chains such as the Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen can be found. South of the Thuringian Basin lies the region's largest mountain range, highlighted by the Thuringian Forest in the northwest, the Thuringian Highland in the central area, and the Franconian Forest in the southeast. This predominantly forested range includes the Großer Beerberg, which, at 983 meters, is Thuringia's highest peak. To the southwest, the Werra River Valley separates the Thuringian Forest from the Rhön Mountains to the west and the Grabfeld plain to the south. Eastern Thuringia, generally defined as the area east of the Saale and Loquitz Valley, features a gradually rising hilly landscape from the flat north to the mountainous south. The Saale in the west and the Weiße Elster in the east are the two major rivers flowing from south to north, creating densely populated valleys in this region. The Jurassic Period, spanning approximately 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 million years ago, was marked by significant geological and climatic transformations. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea began to fragment, forming the northern supercontinent Laurasia and the southern supercontinent Gondwana. This tectonic activity led to the opening of the Gulf of Mexico as a rift developed between North America and the present-day Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. The North Atlantic Ocean was relatively narrow at this time, and the South Atlantic did not form until the subsequent Cretaceous Period, when Gondwana further fragmented. The closing of the Tethys Sea and the emergence of the Neotethys basin were notable geological events. The climate during the Jurassic was predominantly warm, with no significant glaciation or polar ice caps, as there was no landmass located at either pole. The geological record of this period is well-preserved in western Europe, characterized by extensive marine sequences indicative of submersion under shallow tropical seas, exemplified by sites such as the Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site and the notable late Jurassic fossil deposits at Holzmaden and Solnhofen. Conversely, the Jurassic record in North America is less complete, with sparse surface outcrops. Despite the presence of marine deposits from the epicontinental Sundance Sea in parts of the northern plains of the United States and Canada during the late Jurassic, most exposed sediments are continental, including the alluvial deposits of the Morrison Formation. Passengers disembark through the airbridge, while mobile stairs provide the ground crew with additional access to the aircraft's cabin. After the aircraft lands, a dedicated cleaning service readies the cabin for the next group of passengers. Meanwhile, flight catering delivers food and beverages for the upcoming flight. A specialized toilet waste truck empties the onboard waste reservoirs, and a water truck replenishes the aircraft's water supply. Additionally, a fuel transfer vehicle transfers aviation fuel from underground storage tanks to the aircraft's fuel tanks.

For luggage handling, a tractor and its dollies transport baggage from the terminal to the aircraft. Upon the aircraft's arrival and subsequent unloading, these vehicles also convey luggage to the terminal. Hi-loaders are employed to elevate heavy luggage containers to the cargo hold gate, while the ground crew manually loads them into the hold. Following the aircraft’s arrival, the hi-loaders facilitate the unloading process by lowering the containers, which are then placed onto the dollies. The conveyor belt system on a truck is utilized for transporting irregularly shaped or late-arriving luggage. New passengers embark via the airbridge, and the tow tractor subsequently moves the aircraft to a designated taxi area. It is expected that the aircraft will depart from the airport and be airborne within 90 minutes. The airport imposes fees on the airline based on the duration the aircraft remains on the premises.

In 1718, at the request of either Rector Samuel Andrew or Governor Gurdon Saltonstall of the colony, Cotton Mather reached out to Elihu Yale, a successful businessman living in Wales, to seek financial assistance for constructing a new college building. Yale, originally from Boston and whose father, David, was among New Haven's original settlers, was approached largely due to the persuasive efforts of Jeremiah Dummer. Yale, who had amassed a fortune through trade during his time with the East India Company in Madras, generously donated nine bales of goods. These goods were sold for over £560—a significant amount at the time. In recognition of his contribution, Cotton Mather proposed renaming the institution to Yale College. Concurrently, a Harvard alumnus in England persuaded approximately 180 leading intellectuals to donate books to Yale. The 1714 consignment of 500 volumes included modern works on English literature, science, philosophy, and theology, profoundly influencing Yale scholars. Among them, undergraduate Jonathan Edwards encountered John Locke's writings, inspiring his own theological framework known as the "new divinity." By 1722, Rector Samuel Andrew and six colleagues, who formed a study group to explore these new ideas, publicly renounced Calvinism, adopting Arminianism and joining the Church of England. They traveled to England for ordination and returned as Anglican missionaries. In 1745, Thomas Clapp assumed the presidency and endeavored to steer the college back to Calvinist orthodoxy, yet he kept the library accessible. Consequently, students discovered and explored Deist literature within its walls.

Efforts to establish Hebrew as the national language of the Jewish people have not resulted in widespread fluency among Jews globally. Instead, English has become the dominant language of the Jewish diaspora. Historically, many Jews had sufficient knowledge of Hebrew for the study of classical literature, and languages such as Yiddish and Ladino were widely spoken until the early 20th century. Currently, the majority of Jews speak English, which has largely replaced other Jewish vernaculars. The three most commonly spoken languages among Jews today are Hebrew, English, and Russian, with French and Spanish also being prevalent in some regions. Although Yiddish was historically the most spoken Jewish language, its usage has declined significantly due to the Holocaust and the promotion of Modern Hebrew by the Zionist movement and the State of Israel.

In certain regions, the primary language of Jewish communities differs from that of the surrounding population. For example, in Quebec, the Ashkenazi Jewish majority primarily speaks English, whereas the Sephardic minority primarily uses French. Similarly, South African Jews have predominantly adopted English over Afrikaans. In Russia, Czarist and Soviet policies led to Russian replacing Yiddish as the main language among Russian Jews, a trend that extended to adjacent communities. Today, Russian serves as the first language for many Jewish communities in several post-Soviet states, such as Ukraine and Uzbekistan, and for Ashkenazi Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. In North Africa, while Jewish communities are now small and declining, they historically transitioned from multilingualism to predominantly speaking French in Algeria, Morocco, and Tunis, whereas most North Africans continue to use Arabic as their native language.

The region now known as Galicia has a storied past, tracing its human habitation back to the Middle Paleolithic era. Its name is derived from the Gallaeci, Celtic tribes who, during the final millennium BC, thrived north of the Douro River—a territory largely overlapping with the Iron Age Castro culture. By the conclusion of the Cantabrian Wars in 19 BC, Galicia had been absorbed into the sprawling Roman Empire, later being designated a Roman province in the 3rd century AD. The tides of history shifted yet again in 410, when the Germanic Suebi established a kingdom centered in Braga, now part of modern-day Portugal. This kingdom was later subsumed by the Visigoths in 585. When the Arabs swept across the Iberian Peninsula in 711, they overtook the Visigothic territories, only for Galicia to be integrated into the Christian Kingdom of Asturias by 740. Throughout the Middle Ages, Galicia occasionally found itself under the reign of its own monarchs, though more frequently, it was allied with the Kingdom of Leon and subsequently Castile, while preserving its distinct legal traditions and cultural identity. From the 13th century onwards, the Castilian kings, in their role as rulers of Galicia, appointed an Adiantado-mór, whose duties were later assumed by the Governor and Captain General of the Kingdom of Galiza in the late 15th century. This Governor also led the Real Audiencia do Reino de Galicia, a royal tribunal and governing body. By the 16th century, the kingdom's voice was articulated through the Cortes or Junta of the Kingdom of Galicia, an assembly of city deputies, which was forcibly dissolved in 1833 when Galicia was partitioned into four administrative provinces lacking legal cohesion. As the 19th and 20th centuries unfolded, the clamor for self-governance and recognition of Galicia's unique identity grew louder. This fervor culminated in the thwarted Statute of Autonomy in 1936 and ultimately the Statute of Autonomy of 1981, which remains in effect today.

Birds possess a remarkably efficient respiratory system that facilitates the diffusion of oxygen into the bloodstream. Notably, the surface area available for gas exchange in birds is approximately ten times greater than that in mammals, resulting in a higher concentration of blood within their capillaries per unit of lung volume compared to mammals. The arterial system in birds is composed of robust and elastic muscles designed to endure the pressure generated by ventricular constriction. These arteries progressively become more rigid as they extend away from the heart.

Blood is transported through the arteries, which undergo vasoconstriction, into arterioles. These arterioles function as a distribution network, delivering oxygen and nutrients to the body's tissues. As arterioles advance from the heart towards various organs and tissues, they further subdivide to enhance surface area and decelerate blood flow. The transition from arterioles to capillaries marks the site where gas exchange occurs. Capillaries are organized into capillary beds within tissues, where the exchange of oxygen for carbon dioxide waste transpires. The slowed blood flow within these capillary beds optimizes the diffusion of oxygen into tissues.

Once the blood is deoxygenated, it travels through venules and then veins to return to the heart. Unlike arteries, veins are thin and less rigid, as they are not required to withstand high pressure. As blood moves from venules to veins, vasodilation occurs, facilitating its return to the heart. Upon reaching the heart, the blood enters the right atrium, then proceeds to the right ventricle, where it is pumped to the lungs for further gas exchange, exchanging carbon dioxide waste for oxygen. The oxygenated blood then flows from the lungs into the left atrium, subsequently entering the left ventricle, from which it is pumped out to supply the body.

It has since been consistently ranked among the seminal works in hip-hop and among the greatest debut albums by any artist. The album's fourth single, "Jesus Walks," broadened West's audience with its exploration of faith and Christianity. Despite industry predictions that such overt religious themes would hinder its radio success, the song reached the top twenty of the Billboard pop charts. The College Dropout was eventually certified triple platinum in the United States and earned West ten Grammy nominations, including Album of the Year and Best Rap Album, the latter of which it won. Vladimir ascended as the Prince of Novgorod following the death of his father, Sviatoslav I, in 972. However, in 976, he was compelled to flee to Scandinavia after his half-brother, Yaropolk, murdered their sibling Oleg and seized control of Rus. In Scandinavia, with assistance from his relative, Earl Håkon Sigurdsson, the ruler of Norway, Vladimir assembled a formidable Viking army. This alliance enabled him to reclaim Novgorod and Kiev from Yaropolk. As Prince of Kiev, Vladimir's most significant accomplishment was the Christianization of Kievan Rus', which commenced in 988. According to the Primary Chronicle, upon deciding to adopt a new faith over the traditional Slavic paganism, Vladimir dispatched some of his most trusted advisors and warriors as emissaries across Europe. They explored the religious practices of the Christians of the Latin Rite, the Jews, and the Muslims, ultimately reaching Constantinople. They dismissed Islam due to its prohibition of alcohol and Judaism because its deity had allowed the loss of the Jews' homeland. The emissaries found the Roman church's ceremonies unremarkable. However, in Constantinople, they were captivated by the grandeur of Hagia Sophia and the accompanying liturgical service, leading them to favor the Byzantine Rite. Upon returning home, they persuaded Vladimir that this faith was the optimal choice. Consequently, Vladimir traveled to Constantinople and arranged to marry Princess Anna, sister of the Byzantine Emperor Basil II.

Athanasius, a revered figure in early Christianity, vividly recounts his formative years as a student under the tutelage of the martyrs who endured the Great Persecution—Rome's tenth and final assault on Christianity. This brutal campaign, orchestrated by pagan Rome, was most intense in the eastern regions, particularly Egypt and Palestine. Among those martyred was Peter of Alexandria, the 17th archbishop, who met his fate in 311 during the persecution’s final days and may have been one of Athanasius's formative educators. As recounted by Sozomen, Bishop Alexander welcomed Athanasius into his inner circle as a companion and secretary, recognizing his erudition in grammar and rhetoric, and admiring his youthful wisdom and keen intellect.

Egocentrism in adolescents manifests as a self-conscious desire to be valued within peer groups and to attain social acceptance. In contrast to the often conflicting aspects of self-concept, identity embodies a coherent and stable sense of self that persists across various circumstances, encompassing past experiences and future aspirations. While everyone possesses a self-concept, Erik Erikson posited that not all individuals fully achieve a well-defined identity. His theory of developmental stages includes an "identity crisis," during which adolescents are encouraged to explore different possibilities and integrate diverse aspects of themselves before committing to their beliefs. Erikson described the successful resolution of this process as reaching the "identity achievement" stage, yet he emphasized that the challenge of identity is never completely resolved at a single point in time.

Adolescents initially define themselves by their affiliations with particular social groups or "crowds." Clothing, for instance, plays a pivotal role in this process by enabling teenagers to explore new identities, differentiate themselves from their parents, and forge connections with peers. Fashion, with its ever-evolving nature, parallels the transformative journey of adolescent personality development. Through a process of trial and error, adolescents experiment with various styles to find what resonates with both their self-perception and the perceptions of others, thereby gaining a deeper understanding of their identity.

Moreover, as fashion influences adolescents, so too does the media. Modern life is inundated with a constant barrage of images on screens, in print, and on billboards. These images can subconsciously impact self-perception and significantly affect adolescents' sense of identity. James Marcia, a researcher in this field, devised a method to evaluate an individual's progress through these developmental stages. He structured his inquiries into three categories: occupation, ideology, and interpersonal relationships. Responses are assessed based on the extent of exploration and the degree of commitment, leading to classification into one of four identity statuses: a) Identity Diffusion, where all children begin, b) Identity Foreclosure, characterized by commitments made without exploring alternatives, c) Moratorium, the active process of exploration, and d) Identity Achievement, where exploration has culminated in firm commitments.

Stanley Schachter built upon the earlier work of Spanish physician Gregorio Marañón, who conducted experiments by injecting patients with epinephrine and then questioning them about their feelings. Marañón observed that while patients did report feeling something, in the absence of an actual emotion-inducing stimulus, they were unable to interpret their physiological arousal as a specific emotion. Schachter concurred that physiological reactions significantly contribute to emotional experiences. He proposed that these reactions aid in the cognitive appraisal of a physiologically arousing event, and it is this appraisal that defines the subjective emotional experience. Emotions, according to Schachter, result from a two-stage process: general physiological arousal followed by the experience of emotion. For instance, the sight of a bear in the kitchen triggers physiological arousal, such as a pounding heart. The brain quickly assesses the situation, identifies the bear, and interprets the pounding heart as a fear response. Collaborating with his student Jerome Singer, Schachter demonstrated that individuals could exhibit different emotional responses despite being in the same physiological state induced by an epinephrine injection. Subjects expressed either anger or amusement based on the emotions displayed by a confederate in the same environment. Thus, the combination of cognitive appraisal and the physiological effects of adrenaline or a placebo determined the emotional response. This experiment was critiqued in Jesse Prinz's 2004 work, "Gut Reactions."

In the era of Hong Taiji, the corridors of power were graced by the presence of many Han Chinese, including a number of newly surrendered Ming officials. The Manchus, in their wisdom, maintained their supremacy through an ethnic quota system for the highest echelons of the bureaucracy. During his reign, Hong Taiji initiated a profound transformation in the treatment of his Han Chinese subjects. In contrast, his predecessor, Nurhaci, had taken a different approach, treating the Han of Liaodong based on their grain possessions. Those with meager stores, less than five to seven sin, found themselves reduced to servitude, while those with ample reserves were rewarded with land. However, the revolt of 1623 in Liaodong altered Nurhaci's disposition; he grew mistrustful of the Han he had once appeased, enacting policies of discrimination and violence against them. Yet, those Han who had embraced Jurchen ways before 1619 in Jilin were granted parity with the Jurchens, a distinction not afforded to the conquered Han of Liaodong.

Hong Taiji, with a vision more inclusive and strategic, wove these Han into the very fabric of the Jurchen "nation," bestowing upon them the responsibilities of citizenship and the duty of military service. By the year 1648, a mere fraction, less than one-sixth, of the bannermen traced their lineage to Manchu ancestry. The technology-focused website CNET awarded the new Super Slim PlayStation 3 a rating of 4 out of 5 stars, describing it as "Excellent." The review highlighted that the Super Slim version compresses a powerful gaming system into a more compact form while retaining the features of its predecessors, including an extensive gaming library and a robust selection of streaming services. However, CNET criticized the design and disc-loader, noting that the cover sometimes fails to engage properly, likening the experience to using an outdated credit card imprinter. This issue contributes to a perception of cheapness, especially given the convenience of autoloading disc trays in previous models. The review suggested that the change might have been intended to cut costs or save space but ultimately considered it a disadvantage. Additionally, the Super Slim model's price was criticized, as the least expensive version is still higher than the cheapest Slim model. The review argued that the smaller size and larger hard drive do not constitute an upgrade since the hard drive on a Slim model can be easily replaced. On a positive note, CNET praised the ease of accessing the hard drive in the Super Slim model, describing it as the most straightforward yet, with a side panel that slides off to reveal the drive bay. While the Super Slim model is not seen as an upgrade, CNET suggested it might indicate future developments. For potential PS3 buyers, the Super Slim is recommended if they can accept the absence of a slot-loading disc drive.

Y DNA studies suggest a limited number of founders in ancient populations that later diverged and followed distinct migratory routes. In many Jewish populations, these paternal ancestors predominantly originated from the Middle East. For instance, Ashkenazi Jews share more paternal lineages with other Jewish and Middle Eastern groups compared to non-Jewish populations in Eastern Europe, Germany, and the French Rhine Valley. This aligns with Jewish traditions that trace most Jewish paternal origins to the Middle East. In contrast, the maternal lineages of Jewish populations, examined through mitochondrial DNA, are generally more varied. Researchers such as Harry Ostrer and Raphael Falk propose that this diversity indicates Jewish males often found new partners from European and other communities during their diaspora after leaving ancient Israel. However, Behar's research suggests that about 40% of Ashkenazi Jews trace their maternal lineage to just four female founders of Middle Eastern origin. Sephardi and Mizrahi Jewish communities did not show signs of a significant founder effect. Further research by Feder et al. supported the significant non-local maternal origins among Ashkenazi Jews. Reflecting on these findings, the authors suggest that the genetic differences between Jewish and non-Jewish groups are more pronounced than those among various Jewish communities, implying that intra-Jewish differences may be less significant when compared to non-Jewish populations.

This resilience bore fruit during the tumultuous Reform War, as the liberal heart of the land beat steadily, ensuring its survival with only whispers of the chaos that plagued others. The conservative wave in 1858 crashed against the steadfast cliffs of liberal conviction, even as the formidable Zuloaga, with his thousand-strong army, swept through cities like Chihuahua and Parral, casting long shadows but planting no roots.

Yet triumph proved ephemeral as Orozco, after deposing the state governor, found himself a fugitive, seeking refuge in Durango just two months later.

The late 1860s saw the bold stride of conservative General Cajen echo through the valleys and peaks, a storm rolling in from Jalisco. His presence swept through the state like a tempest, shaking the foundations as conservative politicians found their footing and liberal stalwarts like Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni were forced into exile. Cajen seized the state capital, declaring himself governor while marshalling a formidable force to etch his legacy in the dust of La Batalla del Gallo. Yet, despite his fleeting triumphs, the resilient spirit of the liberals smoldered beneath, ready to reignite.
